results.title: [Maurie Fields and Val Jellay Home Movies: Reel 10]
results.brief_description:
This film is a snapshot of a family holiday in Bangkok, Thailand.

The film opens with scenes shot from what could be the floor of a high-rise hotel balcony or window. We see city views of Bangkok showing buildings and cars on the street below, as well as what could be the Royal Bangkok Sports Club and racetrack. There is also evidence of some colonial architecture.

A tourist boat trip through the khlongs (canals) of what could be the Chao Phraya River in the Thonburi area of Bangkok, Thailand, shows snippets of the way of life at the water’s edge. Along the way of the canals and river, we see tropical water plants, temples, traditional and motorised canoes, and square, fishing bag-nets. There are scenes of wooden stilt houses, longtail boats, washing lines and river side stalls.

Originally shot on Super 8mm film

Selected highlight:
00:01:23:00 Temple and wooden structures along the waterside

results.title: [Maurie Fields and Val Jellay Home Movies: Reel 9]
results.brief_description:
This film is a snapshot of a family holiday in Hong Kong.

Some sections of this film have exposure and focus issues, as well as the occasional hair in the gate.

The film opens with Hong Kong city street scenes taken at the busy intersection of Des Voeux Road. We see traffic lights, pedestrians, cars, trams, double-decker buses, city buildings and shop fronts. We see the reputable clothing and apparel store, Mohan’s, on Hankow Road, a Hong Kong and Shanghai Banking Corporation building and signage. There are scenes along the harbour and a trip on a funicular tram to the city heights. This could possibly be the Peak Tram which takes tourists and residents to the upper levels of Hong Kong. We see views of the harbour and skyscrapers, and a number 72 bus to Aberdeen.

Originally shot on Super 8mm film

Selected highlights list:
00:00:03:00 Double-decker buses, pedestrians, cars and trams on city street

00:00:42:00 Mohan’s signage and building

00:02:20:00 Buses, pedestrians and cars

results.title: [Maurie Fields and Val Jellay Home Movies: Reel 8]
results.headline_credit: Australia, Mexico and United States, c. 1960s-1970s
results.brief_description:
This film is a snapshot of a family holiday to the United States of America and Mexico, including a visit to the Universal Studios, San Diego SeaWorld, and to the Mexican border, Tijuana in Mexico.

Some sections of this film have focus issues, as well as the occasional hair in the gate.

The film opens with scenes of the Sandiego SeaWorld. We see people tobogganing on snow, flamingos and the Sandiego SeaWorld skytower.

A trip to Tijuana shows a tourist, possibly Maurie and Val’s son, posing for the camera wearing a sombrero and sitting astride a donkey painted with zebra stripes (also known as a zonkey). Scenes on the street show Maurie amongst the cars and vendors, with signage advertising Bacardi from Cuba and the Los Panchos Coffee Shop.

The next stop on the travel itinerary is Universal Studios in Hollywood. A tram tour of the backlot shows Lakshmi Restaurant, Joe’s Deli, the Hammond and Smith Mortuary, a swinging gorilla that could be King Kong, rolling boulders and the special effect of the collapsing bridge.

Originally shot on Super 8mm film
results.title_for_label: [Maurie Fields and Val Jellay Home Movies: Reel 8]

results.title: [Maurie Fields and Val Jellay Home Movies: Reel 7]
results.brief_description:
This film is a snapshot of a family holiday in Japan, possibly in Nikko.

Nikko is a small city in Japan’s Tochigi Prefecture, in the mountains north of Tokyo.

The film opens with a scene of tourists boarding a Nikko Tour tourist bus on their way to a sightseeing trip to the mountains.

A stop-over sees Maurie’s son slipping and sliding along a snow-covered path and Maurie performing an impromptu ice-skating sequence - without the ice skates.

We see monkeys, probably Japanese Macaques, along the side of the road as cars drive past.

Looking out from the bus window we see a landscape of snow-capped mountains and winding roads at altitude.

Originally shot on Super 8mm film

results.title: [Maurie Fields and Val Jellay Home Movies: Reel 6]
results.brief_description:
This film is a snapshot of a family holiday in Thailand.

Some sections of this film have exposure and focus issues, as well as the occasional hair in the gate.

The film opens with scenes shot from a tourist boat trip through the Khlongs (canals) of what could be the Chao Phraya River in the Thonburi area of Bangkok Thailand. Along the way of the canals and river, we see a convoy of traditional river boats, canoes and rice barges.

There are scenes from what appears to be a “cultural show” performed for tourists. We see a procession of people wearing traditional Thai dress accompanied by decorated elephants. There is a martial arts performance including Kickboxing, Muay Thai and Krabi-Krabong, a weapon based martial art demonstrated using sticks. There are scenes of a cock fight, musicians and men and women performing Lao Kra Top or bamboo dancing.

The film also shows tourists riding elephants.

Originally shot on Super 8mm film

results.title: [Maurie Fields and Val Jellay Home Movies: Reel 5]
results.brief_description:
This film is a snapshot of a family holiday in Thailand and Japan.

The film opens with scenes shot from a tourist boat trip through the Khlongs (canals) of what could be the Chao Phraya River in the Thonburi area of Bangkok Thailand. Along the way of the canals and river, we see tropical water plants, traditional canoes and wooden stilt houses. Washing is strung from a clothes line across the fronts of houses and there are people bathing and cleaning their pots and pans with water scooped from the river.

A stop-over includes scenes of Maurie Fields and Vally Jellay participating in a dance activity along with fellow tourists and children wearing traditional dress.

The family then travel to Japan, taking a train trip to Nikko. Nikko is a small city in Japan’s Tochigi Prefecture, in the mountains north of Tokyo.

Views from the train window include snow-capped mountains, buildings and houses in the snow. We see a Nikko Tobu sign on a railway platform and a welcome sign for the Nikko Kanaya Hotel upon arrival.

People throw snow balls and we see Nikko Tour tourist buses parked along the street beside cars and buildings that reflect the culture and the era.

Originally shot on Super 8mm film

results.title: My Boyfriend Came Back from the War
results.brief_description: My Boyfriend Came Back From the War is a browser-based internet artwork created in 1996 by Russian artist Olia Lialina and is an example of interactive hypertext storytelling.

constellations_other.name: Magic lanterns and internet culture
constellations_other.description: The basic animation techniques of magic lanterns are strangely similar to internet aesthetics.

results.title_for_label: My Boyfriend Came Back from the War
results.description:
My Boyfriend Came Back From the War is a browser-based internet artwork created in 1996 by Russian artist Olia Lialina.

My Boyfriend Came Back From the War is an example of interactive hypertext storytelling. The work consists of nested frames with black and white web pages and (sometimes animated) grainy GIF images. When clicking hyperlinks in the work, the frame splits into smaller frames and the user reveals a nonlinear story about a couple that is reunited after a nameless military conflict. The lovers find it difficult to reconnect; the woman confesses that she has had an affair with a neighbour while the returned soldier proposes marriage. The story unfolds to the point where the screen has become a mosaic of empty black frames.

Olia Lialina calls the work a netfilm, because of its similarity with cinematic narrative. The grainy black-and-white images and intertitles refer to early silent movies. Of its filmic qualities, curator Michael Connor wrote of the work, “the work adapts cinematic montage to the web … separate frames are joined together by HTML code and the browser itself and experienced in both space and in time, employing what Lev Manovich has characterized as spatial and temporal montage.” - Wikipedia
description_for_label:
My Boyfriend Came Back From the War is a browser-based internet artwork created in 1996 by Russian artist Olia Lialina.

My Boyfriend Came Back From the War is an example of interactive hypertext storytelling. The work consists of nested frames with black and white web pages and (sometimes animated) grainy GIF images. When clicking hyperlinks in the work, the frame splits into smaller frames and the user reveals a nonlinear story about a couple that is reunited after a nameless military conflict. The lovers find it difficult to reconnect; the woman confesses that she has had an affair with a neighbour while the returned soldier proposes marriage. The story unfolds to the point where the screen has become a mosaic of empty black frames.

Olia Lialina calls the work a netfilm, because of its similarity with cinematic narrative. The grainy black-and-white images and intertitles refer to early silent movies. Of its filmic qualities, curator Michael Connor wrote of the work, “the work adapts cinematic montage to the web … separate frames are joined together by HTML code and the browser itself and experienced in both space and in time, employing what Lev Manovich has characterized as spatial and temporal montage.” - Wikipedia

results.title: If We Don't, Remember Me
results.brief_description:
IWDRM was a blog of animated movie stills active from 2010 to 2015.

A video installation was shown in exhibitions at the Contemporary Arts Museum (Houston, TX), &FOAM (Amsterdam) and The Event (Birmingham).

constellations_other.name: Magic lanterns and internet culture
constellations_other.description: The basic animation techniques of magic lanterns are strangely similar to internet aesthetics.

results.title: The Thin Blue Line
results.brief_description: Errol Morris’s unique documentary dramatically re-enacts the crime scene and investigation of a police officer’s murder in Dallas in a film that the Criterion Collection describes as “a work of meticulous journalism and gripping drama”.

constellations_other.name: Reasonable doubt
constellations_other.description: Factual media has the power to reframe information and put forth new, persuasive arguments.  For the criminal justice system, where convictions are made based on arguments being convincing beyond a reasonable doubt, True Crime media has the ability to create doubt, right the wrongs of the justice system, and shed new light on closed cases.

constellations_other.name: Presumption of guilt
constellations_other.description: A Constellation looking at true crime documentaries, the nature of innocence and prejudice.

constellations_other.name: Reconstructing reality
constellations_other.description: While documentary pertains to be about the truth, many filmmakers and artists have used ingenious reconstructions to represent an abstracted honesty.

results.description: In this film Randall Adams, serving a life sentence for the murder of a police officer, swears that he did not commit the crime. In the way he dramatises the quest for evidence Morris emphasises the contradictions in the testimony of key witnesses and legal figures involved with the case and the inconclusiveness of the evidence which served to convict Adams, in what becomes an ironic reflection upon the nature of knowledge and truth. As Bill Nichols points out, Morris’s strategy is the converse of that of documentaries which subordinate their own textual voice to that of the witnesses. In the Thin Blue Line the textual voice actually threatens to overwhelm the discrete voices of the social actors (including that of Adams himself) with its own message about the problematics of representations.
description_for_label: In this film Randall Adams, serving a life sentence for the murder of a police officer, swears that he did not commit the crime. In the way he dramatises the quest for evidence Morris emphasises the contradictions in the testimony of key witnesses and legal figures involved with the case and the inconclusiveness of the evidence which served to convict Adams, in what becomes an ironic reflection upon the nature of knowledge and truth. As Bill Nichols points out, Morris’s strategy is the converse of that of documentaries which subordinate their own textual voice to that of the witnesses. In the Thin Blue Line the textual voice actually threatens to overwhelm the discrete voices of the social actors (including that of Adams himself) with its own message about the problematics of representations.
